content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see two sections of tissue that appear to be lymph nodes, given their ovoid shape and surrounding adipose tissue. Both nodes are hypercellular, indicated by the extensive dark purple areas. This suggests either a reactive process, a lymphoproliferative disorder, or metastatic disease. My initial task would be to carefully examine these purple areas for evidence of metastatic carcinoma from the known colorectal primary tumor.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am examining the second lymph node from the top (the bottom-left piece of tissue). The zoom is focused on the periphery of the node, at the interface between the dense cellular lymphoid tissue and the surrounding fat. This is a critical area to assess for extracapsular extension (tumor spreading beyond the lymph node capsule into the fat), which is an important prognostic factor. It's also an area where early metastatic deposits in the subcapsular sinus can be found. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense, monotonous population of small, dark, round cells consistent with lymphocytes. These cells are infiltrating the adipose tissue, which is composed of large, clear fat cells (adipocytes). I do not see the typical features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as malignant glands, large cells with irregular nuclei, or prominent pink cytoplasm. My impression of this specific field is that it represents lymphoid tissue, likely the edge of the lymph node parenchyma. While I would need to examine the entire node, this particular view does not show evidence of metastasis.
